an4.177:1.1: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
an4.177:2.1: “Rāhula, the interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element.
an4.177:2.2: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an4.177:2.3: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.
an4.177:3.1: The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element.
an4.177:3.2: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an4.177:3.3: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.
an4.177:4.1: The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element.
an4.177:4.2: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an4.177:4.3: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.
an4.177:5.1: The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element.
an4.177:5.2: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
an4.177:5.3: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.
an4.177:6.1: When a mendicant sees these four elements as neither self nor belonging to self, they’re called a mendicant who has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”
